prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: zC400258-high resolution
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Deep CO 3-2 observation to constrain properties of molecular outflow.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is simple, because we are requesting deep integration of a single (CO 3-2) wide spectral line. We can spectrally smooth to 80 km/s, which still allows us to map the outflow in a reasonable amount of time, and yet still provide velocity resolution comparable or higher than that achieved with the H-alpha observations.

The ALMA Cycle 2 CO 3-2 observations of zC400258 have a resolution =0.5"x0.9" (with Briggs weighting; 4x7.5 kpc), while the SINFONI outflows have been mapped with a resolution of 0.23". The source is compact, with little H-alpha emission on scales >0.7" per velocity channel (Fig 1, bottom left). For the CO observations proposed here, configuration C36-6 with maximum ~2 km baselines, will more than double our current spatial resolution and a deeper integration will result in a beam of ~0.3" resolution, sufficient for our goals.

For zC400258 the Cycle 2 data achieved 0.25 mJy/beam rms in 80 km/s averaged channels with Briggs weighting (spatial resolution 0.5x0.9) and 40 minutes of integration on source. The Cycle 2 data already show the presence of a broad component (Fig. 1, top row), but with low S/N. The intensity in the CO narrow component ~1.1 Jy km/s, with a sensitivity of 0.25 mJy in 80 km/s channels. The red high velocity component has ~0.24 Jy km/s, with a peak of ~1 mJy/beam. The CO emission in both the narrow and broad components is more compact than the Cycle 2 beam, so we expect comparable peak flux densities in both line components in the higher resolution observations proposed here. Measuring the spatial extent and the outflow velocity requires a S/N of ~10 in the broad component. We thus request a sensitivity of ~0.1 mJy/beam smoothing to 80 km/s resolution, which will take ~4.5 hours on source or 7.7 hours with all calibrations and overheads. Smoothing to 80 km/s allows us to map the outflow in a reasonable amount of time, and yet still achieve a velocity resolution comparable or higher than that achieved with the H-alpha observations.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Outflow Detection GS3_19791 (K20-ID5)
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO detection of an outflow in one of the strongest H-alpha broad component sources from SINS/KMOS3D

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is simple, because we are requesting deep integration of a single (CO 3-2) wide spectral line. We can spectrally smooth to 80 km/s, which still provides a velocity resolution comparable or higher than that achieved with the H-alpha observations.

For detecting molecular outflows in GS3_19791, we propose conservative, ~1" observations comparable to the rest-frame optical source size), which would be provided by the C36-3 or C36-4 configurations.

To estimate the expected CO 3-2 fluxes, we use the molecular gas scaling relations for main-sequence SFGs of Genzel et al 2015, who have derived accurate molecular gas fraction scalings with redshift, M*, and sSFR for over 1000 galaxies with CO or dust based molecular gas masses. Given SFRs and M* for the 2 sources listed in Table 1 and assuming line widths similar to zC400528, we expect CO integrated fluxes of ~1.2 Jy km/s in GS3_19791. To get a detection comparable to that of the Cycle 2 data of zC400528, we need to reach ~0.24 mJy/beam rms in 80 km/s channels (~48 min on source, or 1.3 hours total) for GS3_19791.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Outflow Detection COS4_11363
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: CO detection of an outflow in one of the strongest H-alpha broad component sources from SINS/KMOS3D

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: The correlator setup is simple, because we are requesting deep integration of a single (CO 3-2) wide spectral line. Even with heavy spectral smoothing of 100 km/s, which is necessary given the expected line strength, we still achieve a spectral resolution comparable to that of the H-alpha observations.

For detecting molecular outflows in COS4_11363, we propose conservative, ~1" observations (comparable to the rest-frame optical source size), which would be provided by the C36-3 or C36-4 configurations.

To estimate the expected CO 3-2 fluxes, we use the molecular gas scaling relations for main-sequence SFGs of Genzel et al 2015, who have derived accurate molecular gas fraction scalings with redshift, M*, and sSFR for over 1000 galaxies with CO or dust based molecular gas masses. Given SFRs and M* for the 2 sources listed in Table 1 and assuming line widths similar to zC400528, we expect CO integrated fluxes of ~0.7 Jy km/s in COS4_11363. To get a detection comparable to that of the Cycle 2 data of zC400528, we need to reach ~0.14 mJy/beam rms in 100 km/s channels (heavier smoothing for this expected weaker source; ~1.9 hours on source or 3.2 hours total) for COS4_11363.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: This proposal aims to investigate the role of nuclear driven outflows in quenching star formation above the Schechter mass (log M*>10.9) by detecting high velocity molecular outflows in some of the same massive SFGs that exhibit prominent nuclear ionized outflows. The first goal is to spatially resolve a molecular outflow we recently discovered with ALMA in the massive star forming galaxy (SFG) zC400528 at z=2.39 (Cycle 2, 2013.1.0092S: P.I. Genzel), to compare the extent of the molecular outflow with that of the ionized H-alpha outflow at comparable spatial resolutions, and to determine the molecular outflow velocities and outflow and momentum rates. We also request time to search for nuclear molecular outflows at lower spatial resolution in 2 additional sources - those with the strongest H-alpha nuclear broad components from our IFU surveys with the ESO VLT. These ALMA Band 3 CO 3-2 observations will provide direct evidence of feedback-driven quenching in normal, massive main-sequence galaxies in the component that carries most of the mass - the cold molecular gas.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Cosmology and the High Redshift Universe
